trans-unit.source: Linear Correlation
trans-unit.target: Linear Correlation

trans-unit.source: Calculates the linear correlation between column values in a dataset
trans-unit.target: Calculates the linear correlation between column values in a dataset

trans-unit.source: Category: <legacyLink xlink:href="8A248CBA-24AA-4779-AAD6-35D73A0A2340" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Statistical Functions</legacyLink>
trans-unit.target: Category: <legacyLink xlink:href="8A248CBA-24AA-4779-AAD6-35D73A0A2340" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Statistical Functions</legacyLink>

trans-unit.source: Module Overview
trans-unit.target: Module Overview

trans-unit.source: You can use the <ui>Linear Correlation</ui> module to compute a set of Pearson correlation coefficients, (often denoted as <math>r</math>) for each possible pair of variables in the input dataset.
trans-unit.target: You can use the <ui>Linear Correlation</ui> module to compute a set of Pearson correlation coefficients, (often denoted as <math>r</math>) for each possible pair of variables in the input dataset.

trans-unit.source: The Pearson correlation coefficient ranges in value from +1 to -1, where +1 indicates a strong linear relationship, and -1 indicates no linear relationship between the two variables.
trans-unit.target: The Pearson correlation coefficient ranges in value from +1 to -1, where +1 indicates a strong linear relationship, and -1 indicates no linear relationship between the two variables.

trans-unit.source: The interpretation of the coefficients depends very much on the problem you are modeling and the variables you are studying.
trans-unit.target: The interpretation of the coefficients depends very much on the problem you are modeling and the variables you are studying.

trans-unit.source: For example, if you are certain the variables are unrelated and yet the Pearson’s correlation coefficient is positive, you should investigate further.
trans-unit.target: For example, if you are certain the variables are unrelated and yet the Pearson’s correlation coefficient is positive, you should investigate further.

trans-unit.source: Conversely, if you use linear correlation on two variables that you know to be perfectly correlated, and the coefficient values are not what you expect, it might indicate a problem in the data.
trans-unit.target: Conversely, if you use linear correlation on two variables that you know to be perfectly correlated, and the coefficient values are not what you expect, it might indicate a problem in the data.

trans-unit.source: Thus it is important to understand the context of the data when reporting and interpreting Pearson's correlation coefficient.
trans-unit.target: Thus it is important to understand the context of the data when reporting and interpreting Pearson's correlation coefficient.

trans-unit.source: How to Use Linear Correlation
trans-unit.target: How to Use Linear Correlation

trans-unit.source: There are no parameters to set for <ui>Linear Correlation</ui>.
trans-unit.target: There are no parameters to set for <ui>Linear Correlation</ui>.

trans-unit.source: Pearson’s correlation is calculated for all numeric columns in the dataset that are passed as input.
trans-unit.target: Pearson’s correlation is calculated for all numeric columns in the dataset that are passed as input.

trans-unit.source: Given two feature columns, the <ui>Linear Correlation</ui> module returns the scalar Pearson product moment (sample) correlation coefficient.
trans-unit.target: Given two feature columns, the <ui>Linear Correlation</ui> module returns the scalar Pearson product moment (sample) correlation coefficient.

trans-unit.source: Given a matrix, the <ui>Linear Correlation</ui> module returns a set of Pearson product moment correlations between each pair of feature columns.
trans-unit.target: Given a matrix, the <ui>Linear Correlation</ui> module returns a set of Pearson product moment correlations between each pair of feature columns.

trans-unit.source: The <ui>Linear Correlation</ui> module can process only numeric values.
trans-unit.target: The <ui>Linear Correlation</ui> module can process only numeric values.

trans-unit.source: All other types of values, including missing values, non-numeric values, and categorical values, are treated as NaNs.
trans-unit.target: All other types of values, including missing values, non-numeric values, and categorical values, are treated as NaNs.

trans-unit.source: To avoid creating a lot of unnecessary columns of NaNs, we recommend that you use <link xlink:href="1ec722fa-b623-4e26-a44e-a50c6d726223" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Project Columns</link> to pass in only the columns for which you want to compute coefficients.
trans-unit.target: To avoid creating a lot of unnecessary columns of NaNs, we recommend that you use <link xlink:href="1ec722fa-b623-4e26-a44e-a50c6d726223" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Project Columns</link> to pass in only the columns for which you want to compute coefficients.

trans-unit.source: <ui>Linear Correlation</ui> is intended to be used with data that has no missing values.
trans-unit.target: <ui>Linear Correlation</ui> is intended to be used with data that has no missing values.

trans-unit.source: Before running this module, use <link xlink:href="d2c5ca2f-7323-41a3-9b7e-da917c99f0c4" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Clean Missing Data</link> or other methods to impute missing values.
trans-unit.target: Before running this module, use <link xlink:href="d2c5ca2f-7323-41a3-9b7e-da917c99f0c4" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Clean Missing Data</link> or other methods to impute missing values.

trans-unit.source: Also, be sure you replace placeholders with other values.
trans-unit.target: Also, be sure you replace placeholders with other values.

trans-unit.source: For example, if NaNs were inserted for missing values when the dataset was loaded from the source, it could cause an error.
trans-unit.target: For example, if NaNs were inserted for missing values when the dataset was loaded from the source, it could cause an error.

trans-unit.source: If a placeholder (such as 999 or -1) was used, it could cause bad results.
trans-unit.target: If a placeholder (such as 999 or -1) was used, it could cause bad results.

trans-unit.source: Technical Notes
trans-unit.target: Technical Notes

trans-unit.source: If the column that is passed as input contains scalars, the input arrays (<legacyItalic>x</legacyItalic> and <legacyItalic>y</legacyItalic>) are treated as vectors and the Pearson product moment correlation is computed as follows:
trans-unit.target: If the column that is passed as input contains scalars, the input arrays (<legacyItalic>x</legacyItalic> and <legacyItalic>y</legacyItalic>) are treated as vectors and the Pearson product moment correlation is computed as follows:

trans-unit.source: In this formula, each array contains <legacyItalic>n</legacyItalic> elements and the means of the <legacyItalic>x</legacyItalic> and <legacyItalic>y</legacyItalic> samples are µ<subscript>x</subscript> and µ<subscript>y</subscript> respectively.
trans-unit.target: In this formula, each array contains <legacyItalic>n</legacyItalic> elements and the means of the <legacyItalic>x</legacyItalic> and <legacyItalic>y</legacyItalic> samples are µ<subscript>x</subscript> and µ<subscript>y</subscript> respectively.

trans-unit.source: For a matrix, a matrix of data (<legacyItalic>X</legacyItalic>) is input, in which each column represents a vector of values.
trans-unit.target: For a matrix, a matrix of data (<legacyItalic>X</legacyItalic>) is input, in which each column represents a vector of values.

trans-unit.source: The data matrix should be <legacyItalic>n</legacyItalic>-by-<legacyItalic>m</legacyItalic>.
trans-unit.target: The data matrix should be <legacyItalic>n</legacyItalic>-by-<legacyItalic>m</legacyItalic>.

trans-unit.source: The output is the <legacyItalic>m</legacyItalic>-by-<legacyItalic>m</legacyItalic> matrix, <legacyItalic>R</legacyItalic> as defined by
trans-unit.target: The output is the <legacyItalic>m</legacyItalic>-by-<legacyItalic>m</legacyItalic> matrix, <legacyItalic>R</legacyItalic> as defined by

trans-unit.source: In this formula, μ<subscript>x</subscript> represents the mean value of the column <legacyItalic>x</legacyItalic><subscript>i</subscript>.
trans-unit.target: In this formula, μ<subscript>x</subscript> represents the mean value of the column <legacyItalic>x</legacyItalic><subscript>i</subscript>.

trans-unit.source: The elements at <subscript>I,j</subscript> always equal 1, as they represent the correlation of a vector with itself.
trans-unit.target: The elements at <subscript>I,j</subscript> always equal 1, as they represent the correlation of a vector with itself.

trans-unit.source: Exception
trans-unit.target: Exception

trans-unit.source: Description
trans-unit.target: Description

trans-unit.source: Exception occurs if one or more of inputs are null or empty.
trans-unit.target: Exception occurs if one or more of inputs are null or empty.

trans-unit.source: Exception occurs if the number of columns in some of the datasets passed to the module is too small.
trans-unit.target: Exception occurs if the number of columns in some of the datasets passed to the module is too small.

trans-unit.source: Exception occurs if the number of rows in some of the datasets passed to the module is too small.
trans-unit.target: Exception occurs if the number of rows in some of the datasets passed to the module is too small.
